Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Foundations of Wireless Interfering Cellular Networks With and Without Cooperation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate interfering cellular networks, which are networks formed by operating multiple cells of a traditional cellular network over the same frequency. In particular, it will develop efficient communication schemes for such networks that (a) deal with interfering data flows between multiple source-destination pairs (b) include cooperative strategies between nodes to exploit resources such as a wired back bone of constrained capacity and connectivity between access points and (c) robustly cope with channel uncertainty. Throughout, approximated capacity characterizations or those that are amenable to computation will be sought, with an emphasis on methods that scale well to a larger number of users.

The goal is to develop improved alternatives to communication methods employed in current cellular networks. The importance of such improved methods in the design of future generations of these networks is evident from the e-commerce that such networks enable, the information they make easily accessible and the increased efficiency of organizations they make possible today.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The information-theoretic limits of networks of various topologies under various settings of channel state information at the transmitter (CSIT) have been established. CSIT settings include perfect, delayed, no and a combnation thereof and mixed CSIT. The topologies of the networks include classical ones such as the Z, interference, broadcast and cyclic Z interference channels and novel ones introduced in this project which we refer to as the MAC-IC-MAC. Multiple information theoretic metrics are considered including the degrees of freedom (DoF) region, the generalized degrees of freedom (GDoF) region and constant gap to capacity in the increasing order of accuracy (and difficulty) of the resulting models.

The DoF regions of the MIMO Z interference channel were established under delayed and mixed CSIT. The DoF region of the MIMO interference channel were established under hydbrid CSIT models (of a mixture of delayed and perfect CSIT). The DoF regions of the 2-user MIMO broadcast channel with private (unicast) and common (multicast) messages were established for 9 different hybrid CSIT settings of no/delayed/perfect CSIT for each of the two channel matrices. The DoF regions under perfect and delayed CSIT assumptions were found for the cyclic K-user MIMO Z interference channel.

The GDoF regions of the MIMO Z interference channel were established under the delayed CSIT setting. This work was extended to the MIMO two-sided symmetric interference channel by obtainin lower and upper bounds on the symmetric GDoF which were shown to coincide for strong interference and a range of weak interference settings.

A unified theory of the multiple access channel and the interference channel was developed via the consideration of a new network topology we call the MAC-IC-MAC. Inner and outer bouds were obtained for the semi-deterministic MAC-IC-MAC which were shown to be within a quantifiable gap of each other. These bounds were specialized and evaluated for the scalar and vector (MIMO) Gaussian MAC-IC-MACs to obtain inner and outer bounds that were shown to be withn a constant gap of each other independent of all channel parameters. These bounds were then used to evaluate the GDoF regions of the Gaussian MAC-IC-MAC.
